cwe_description: The software reads data past the end, or before the beginning, of an intended buffer. This can lead to crashes, information disclosure, or arbitrary code execution.
explanation: The code retrieves an offset from pZip->m_pState->m_central_dir_offsets using file_index. While file_index is checked against pZip->m_total_files, the retrieved offset value itself is then used to access pZip->m_pState->m_central_dir without any bounds validation against the size of m_central_dir. An attacker could craft a malicious zip file containing an out-of-bounds offset in m_central_dir_offsets, leading to an out-of-bounds read when m_central_dir is accessed.

cwe_description: The software reads data past the end, or before the beginning, of an intended buffer. This can lead to crashes, information disclosure, or arbitrary code execution.
explanation: The code retrieves an offset from pZip->m_pState->m_central_dir_offsets using file_index. While file_index is checked against pZip->m_total_files, the retrieved offset value itself is then used to access pZip->m_pState->m_central_dir without any bounds validation against the size of m_central_dir. An attacker could craft a malicious zip file containing an out-of-bounds offset in m_central_dir_offsets, leading to an out-of-bounds read when m_central_dir is accessed.

cwe_description: The product reads data past the end, or before the beginning, of an intended buffer. This can lead to crashes, information disclosure, or other undefined behavior.
explanation: The code retrieves an offset from pZip->m_pState->m_central_dir_offsets using a bounds-checked file_index. However, the retrieved offset is then used as an index into pZip->m_pState->m_central_dir without any further bounds validation. If a malicious or corrupted zip file provides an offset that points beyond the allocated size of pZip->m_pState->m_central_dir, an out-of-bounds read will occur, potentially leading to information disclosure or a crash.
